tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires finding the natural frequencies of a 2-DOF system and then extracting a numerical value. It involves setting up an eigenvalue problem and solving for the eigenvalues, which represent the squares of the natural frequencies. It requires knowledge of vibration theory and linear algebra, thus integrating multiple concepts.

answer_validation.reasoning: The equations of motion can be written in matrix form as [M]\{\ddot{x}\} + [K]\{x\} = 0 with [M] = m\begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{bmatrix} and [K] = k\begin{bmatrix}2 & -1 \\ -1 & 2\end{bmatrix}. For free vibration, assume harmonic motion \{x\} = \{X\} e^{i\omega t}, giving the eigenvalue problem ([K] - \omega^2 [M])\{X\} = 0. Non-trivial solutions require \det([K] - \omega^2 [M]) = 0. Substituting the matrices and dividing by k, we get \det\left(\begin{bmatrix}2 - \lambda & -1 \\ -1 & 2 - \lambda\end{bmatrix}\right) = 0 where \lambda = \dfrac{m\omega^2}{k}. The determinant is (2 - \lambda)^2 - 1 = 0, so (2 - \lambda)^2 = 1, giving 2 - \lambda = \pm 1. Thus \lambda_1 = 1 and \lambda_2 = 3. Hence \omega_1^2 = \dfrac{k}{m}, \omega_2^2 = \dfrac{3k}{m}. The larger natural frequency is \omega_2 = \sqrt{3}\,\sqrt{\dfrac{k}{m}}. Comparing with \omega = \alpha \sqrt{k/m}, we identify \alpha = \sqrt{3} \approx 1.732, which rounds to 1.73, lying in the official range 1.72 to 1.74.

step_by_step: Write the equations of motion in matrix form: [M]\{\ddot{x}\} + [K]\{x\} = 0 with [M] = mI and [K] = k\begin{bmatrix}2 & -1 \\ -1 & 2\end{bmatrix}.
Assume harmonic free vibration: \{x\} = \{X\} e^{i\omega t}, which gives ( [K] - \omega^2 [M] )\{X\} = 0.
For non-trivial mode shapes, set the determinant to zero: \det([K] - \omega^2 [M]) = 0.
Introduce the non-dimensional eigenvalue \lambda = \dfrac{m\omega^2}{k} and form the characteristic matrix: \begin{bmatrix}2 - \lambda & -1 \\ -1 & 2 - \lambda\end{bmatrix}.
Compute the determinant: (2 - \lambda)^2 - 1 = 0, solve to get \lambda_1 = 1 and \lambda_2 = 3.
Convert back to frequencies: \omega_1^2 = \dfrac{k}{m}, \omega_2^2 = \dfrac{3k}{m}. The larger frequency is \omega_2 = \sqrt{3}\,\sqrt{k/m}.
Compare with the given form \omega = \alpha \sqrt{k/m} to identify \alpha = \sqrt{3} \approx 1.73 (rounded to two decimal places).

topic.name: Vibration of multi-degree-of-freedom systems
topic.syllabus_ref: Vibrations: Free and forced vibration of single and multi degree of freedom systems

essential: Free vibration of undamped single degree of freedom systems
Matrix form of equations of motion for multi-degree-of-freedom systems
Concept of natural frequency and mode shapes
helpful: Lagrange\'s equations for deriving equations of motion
Physical interpretation of coupled spring-mass systems

Main Concept: requires: Free vibration theory for SDOF systems
enables: Modal analysis of larger MDOF systems
enables: Understanding resonance and vibration control in aerospace structures

difficulty_factors: Requires setting up and solving a 2x2 determinant correctly
Students must recognize the relation between eigenvalue \lambda and \omega^2
Careful algebra is needed to avoid sign or arithmetic errors

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.text_snippet: The free vibration of an undamped multi-degree-of-freedom system is governed by [M]{\ddot{u}} + [K]{u} = 0. Assuming harmonic motion leads to the eigenvalue problem ([K] - \omega^2[M]){U} = 0, whose solution gives the natural frequencies and mode shapes.

textbook_references.author: Alok Sinha
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a two-degree-of-freedom spring-mass system, the characteristic equation is obtained from the determinant of the dynamic stiffness matrix, yielding two natural frequencies.

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.text_snippet: The natural frequency of a single-degree-of-freedom spring-mass system is given by \omega_n = \sqrt{k/m}. This concept extends to multi-degree-of-freedom systems through eigenvalue analysis.

video_references.topic_covered: Equation of motion and harmonic solution for multi-degree-of-freedom systems

video_references.professor: Prof. S.K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Forced vibration and natural frequencies of a 2-DOF spring-mass system

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Matrix formulation \u2192 Harmonic assumption \u2192 Eigenvalue problem \u2192 Characteristic equation \u2192 Solve for eigenvalues \u2192 Extract natural frequencies \u2192 Identify alpha
key_insights: Recognize that natural frequencies of an undamped MDOF system come from the eigenvalues of [K] - \omega^2[M].
Non-dimensionalizing with \lambda = m\omega^2/k simplifies the algebra.
The larger eigenvalue corresponds to the higher natural frequency; here \lambda_2 = 3 gives \omega_2 = \sqrt{3}\sqrt{k/m}.

formulas_principles.name: Matrix equation of motion for undamped MDOF system
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to linear, time-invariant, undamped multi-degree-of-freedom systems in free vibration
formulas_principles.relevance: Starting point to derive natural frequencies via eigenvalue analysis

formulas_principles.name: Eigenvalue form of vibration problem
formulas_principles.conditions: Obtained by assuming harmonic motion x = X e^{i\omega t}
formulas_principles.relevance: Core equation whose non-trivial solutions define natural frequencies and mode shapes

formulas_principles.name: Characteristic equation for natural frequencies
formulas_principles.conditions: Condition for non-trivial solution of homogeneous linear algebraic system
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute the eigenvalues (and hence natural frequencies)

formulas_principles.name: Natural frequency of SDOF spring-mass system
formulas_principles.conditions: Undamped single degree of freedom with stiffness k and mass m
formulas_principles.relevance: Provides the base frequency scale \sqrt{k/m} used in expressing the 2-DOF frequencies

industry_examples: Vibration analysis of aircraft wing sections modeled as 2-DOF systems to estimate bending-torsion coupled natural frequencies.
Design of vibration absorbers where a secondary mass-spring is tuned to a specific mode of a primary structure.
specific_systems: Simplified 2-DOF model of a helicopter rotor blade with flap and lag degrees of freedom.
Two-mass landing gear models used to study gear strut and wheel hop vibrations.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate estimation of natural frequencies in multi-degree-of-freedom systems is crucial to avoid resonance with engine orders, aerodynamic excitations, or ground-induced vibrations, which can lead to fatigue damage or catastrophic failure in aerospace structures.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using det([K] + \omega^2[M]) = 0 instead of det([K] - \omega^2[M]) = 0, leading to wrong eigenvalues.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Sign conventions in the harmonic assumption x = X e^{i\omega t} can be confusing, and some students mix up the resulting algebraic form.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Derive the eigenvalue equation carefully from [M]\ddot{x} + [K]x = 0 using x = X e^{i\omega t} and verify that \ddot{x} = -\omega^2 X e^{i\omega t}, giving ([K] - \omega^2[M])X = 0.
common_mistakes.consequence: Yields incorrect natural frequencies and completely wrong numerical answer for \alpha.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to non-dimensionalize and directly solving with k and m inside the determinant, causing algebraic clutter and errors.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They try to carry physical parameters throughout instead of simplifying with a dimensionless eigenvalue.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Introduce \lambda = m\omega^2/k early, so the characteristic matrix becomes numeric (2 - \lambda, -1, etc.), making determinant evaluation straightforward.
common_mistakes.consequence: Increases chance of arithmetic mistakes and wastes exam time.

common_mistakes.mistake: Picking the smaller eigenvalue (\lambda = 1) as the \"larger\" natural frequency by misinterpreting the question.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They confuse eigenvalues \lambda with frequencies \omega, or overlook the word \"larger\" in the question.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that \omega^2 is proportional to the eigenvalue; larger \lambda means larger \omega. Explicitly compute both \omega_1 and \omega_2 and then choose the larger.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives \alpha = 1 instead of \sqrt{3}, leading to a clearly wrong answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rounding \sqrt{3} too coarsely (e.g., 1.7 or 1.8) instead of to two decimal places.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They approximate square roots mentally without checking with a calculator.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Know common roots: \sqrt{2} \approx 1.41, \sqrt{3} \approx 1.73, \sqrt{5} \approx 2.24. For a 2-decimal answer, quickly verify with a calculator if allowed.
common_mistakes.consequence: May fall outside the accepted range, losing marks despite correct method.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: MDOF modes: K minus omega-squared M gives \"OK\" frequencies
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When setting up the characteristic equation for natural frequencies

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Two masses, three springs: eigenvalues often come as 1 and 3
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Typical eigenvalues for symmetric 2-DOF spring-mass with equal masses and symmetric stiffness
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Quick checking of results for symmetric 2-DOF systems

flashcards.front: What matrix equation gives natural frequencies for an undamped MDOF system starting from [M]\ddot{x} + [K]x = 0?
flashcards.back: Assume x = X e^{i\omega t}, then ([K] - \omega^2[M])X = 0. Non-trivial solutions require det([K] - \omega^2[M]) = 0.

flashcards.front: For a 2-DOF system with [K] = k[[2, -1], [-1, 2]] and [M] = mI, what are the eigenvalues \lambda = m\omega^2/k?
flashcards.back: Solve det([[2 - \lambda, -1], [-1, 2 - \lambda]]) = 0. This gives (2 - \lambda)^2 - 1 = 0, so \lambda_1 = 1 and \lambda_2 = 3.

flashcards.front: Given \lambda_1 = 1 and \lambda_2 = 3 for a 2-DOF system, express the two natural frequencies in terms of k and m.
flashcards.back: Since \lambda = m\omega^2/k, we have \omega_1^2 = k/m and \omega_2^2 = 3k/m. Thus \omega_1 = \sqrt{k/m}, \omega_2 = \sqrt{3}\,\sqrt{k/m}.

flashcards.front: What sign error should you avoid when deriving the eigenvalue equation from [M]\ddot{x} + [K]x = 0?
flashcards.back: Do not write ([K] + \omega^2[M])X = 0. Using x = X e^{i\omega t} gives \ddot{x} = -\omega^2 X e^{i\omega t}, so the correct form is ([K] - \omega^2[M])X = 0.

flashcards.front: What is the numerical value of \sqrt{3} rounded to two decimal places?

real_world_context.application: Coupled vibration analysis of aircraft wings and control surfaces
real_world_context.industry_example: A simplified 2-DOF model of a wing with bending and torsion degrees of freedom is used to estimate coupled natural frequencies to avoid flutter when excited by aerodynamic loads.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If natural frequencies are miscalculated, the structure may resonate with aerodynamic or engine excitation, leading to excessive vibration, fatigue, or catastrophic failure.

real_world_context.application: Design of tuned mass dampers in aerospace structures
real_world_context.industry_example: A small mass-spring system is attached to a satellite panel to shift or absorb energy at a specific mode; accurate 2-DOF frequency prediction ensures proper tuning.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect tuning reduces effectiveness of vibration control, potentially compromising instrument performance or structural integrity.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize this as a standard 2-DOF eigenvalue problem: quickly form the 2x2 characteristic matrix, use \lambda = m\omega^2/k to simplify, solve the quadratic, and pick the larger frequency. It is algebra-light and high scoring.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck but you see symmetric [K] and equal masses, typical eigenvalues are often 1 and 3; the larger frequency factor is then \sqrt{3} \approx 1.73.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes: 1 minute to set up and compute determinant, 1 minute to solve for \lambda and extract \alpha.

search_keywords: two degree of freedom spring mass system natural frequencies
eigenvalues of K minus omega squared M

alternative_methods.name: Mode shape assumption and physical reasoning
alternative_methods.description: Instead of full matrix algebra, assume symmetric and antisymmetric mode shapes due to system symmetry: for the in-phase mode, set x1 = x2; for the out-of-phase mode, set x1 = -x2. Substitute each into the original equations to solve for the corresponding \omega^2 directly.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Very quick for symmetric systems, provides physical insight into mode shapes. Cons: Relies on recognizing symmetry; not easily generalizable to asymmetric or higher-DOF systems.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When the system is clearly symmetric (equal masses, symmetric stiffness) and you want a fast solution or physical understanding of modes.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Natural frequencies of flexible modes (e.g., wing bending and torsion) interact with rigid-body dynamics, influencing flutter and aeroelastic stability.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Eigenvalues of the system matrix in state-space form determine stability and dynamic response, analogous to vibration eigenvalues.
connections_to_other_subjects.Mathematics: Linear algebra concepts such as eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and determinants are central to solving MDOF vibration problems.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Satellite appendage vibrations (solar panels, antennas) are modeled as MDOF systems whose modes affect pointing accuracy and control.

deeper_dive_topics: Modal analysis and orthogonality of mode shapes in MDOF systems
Effect of damping on multi-degree-of-freedom natural frequencies and mode shapes
Finite element modeling of continuous structures leading to large MDOF vibration problems
Aeroelastic flutter analysis using coupled structural and aerodynamic modes

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Free and forced vibration of single and multi degree of freedom systems
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question is a direct and appropriate test of basic MDOF vibration analysis, aligning well with the stated syllabus and suitable for a 2-mark NAT.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general background on SDOF and MDOF vibration equations, matrix form [M]{uÂ¨} + [K]{u} = 0, and an example 2-DOF system with natural frequencies derived via determinant of the dynamic stiffness matrix. Although not the exact same numerical system, the methodology and formulas were directly applicable. Detailed eigenvalue computation for this specific stiffness matrix was done using internal knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the corresponding normalized mode shapes for each natural frequency of the same 2-DOF system.
Modify the system to have unequal masses or stiffnesses and ask for both natural frequencies numerically.
Introduce light damping and ask for the damped natural frequencies and modal damping ratios.
Apply a harmonic force on one mass and ask for the steady-state amplitude at resonance for each mode.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The equations of motion for a two degrees of freedom undamped spring-mass system are: m x_doubledot_1 + 2k x_1 - k x_2 = 0; m x_doubledot_2 - k x_1 + 2k x_2 = 0. where m and k represent mass and stiffness respectively, in corresponding SI units, and x1 and x2 are the degrees of freedom. The larger of the two natural frequencies is given by: omega = alpha sqrt(k/m) rad/s. The value of alpha is ________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
